travel_essentials.title: Transit card: T-money / WOWPASS
travel_essentials.desc: Subway + bus are easiest with a transit card. You can recharge at convenience stores and stations.

travel_essentials.title: Maps: KakaoMap / Naver Map
travel_essentials.desc: Google Maps can be limited for walking routes. Install KakaoMap or Naver Map for better directions.

travel_essentials.title: SIM / eSIM
travel_essentials.desc: For stable data, buy a SIM/eSIM at the airport or online. Keep your passport handy.

travel_essentials.title: Cash vs card
travel_essentials.desc: Most places accept cards, but markets and small stalls may prefer cash. Carry a small amount of KRW.

travel_essentials.title: Trash & recycling
travel_essentials.desc: Public trash bins are rare. Carry a small bag and sort waste when possible.

travel_essentials.title: Emergency numbers
travel_essentials.desc: Police 112, Fire/Ambulance 119. For tourist help: 1330 (Korea Travel Hotline).

trending.title: Pop-up stores & concept spaces
trending.desc: Pop-ups rotate fast (often weekly). Seongsu and Hongdae are common areas—check Instagram posts before going.

trending.title: Café hopping
trending.desc: Many cafés are built for photos + desserts. Go off-peak to avoid long lines.

trending.title: Photo booths
trending.desc: Self-photo studios and booths are everywhere. Bring a friend or use the remote option.

major_issues.title: Peak crowd times
major_issues.desc: Weekends + evenings can be packed in popular districts. If you hate crowds, go weekday mornings.

major_issues.title: Seasonal weather swings
major_issues.desc: Korea can change fast by season. Check weather + air quality before a day trip.

major_issues.title: Reservation-only spots
major_issues.desc: Some restaurants and experiences require booking. If a place is viral, assume you need a reservation.
